chapter.title: Components and configuration of the &program_name; mixnet
chapter.para: This section of the &program_name; technical documentation provides an introduction to the software components that make up &program_name; and guidance on how to configure each component. The intended reader is a system administrator who wants to implement a working, production &program_name; network.
For information about the theory and design of this software, see . For a quickly deployable, non-production test network (primarily for use by developers), see .

section.title: Understanding the &program_name; components
section.para: The core of &program_name; consists of two program executables, voting and server. Running the voting commmand creates a directory authority node, or dirauth, that functions as part of an internal public-key infrastructure (PKI). Running the server creates either a mix node, a gateway node, or a service node, depending on the configuration. Configuration settings are provided in an associated katzenpost-authority.toml or katzenpost.toml file respectively. A configuration guide is provided in .

In addition to the core components, &program_name; also supports connections to client applications hosted externally to the mix network and communicating with it through gateway nodes. A model mix network is shown in Figure 1..

caption.para: Figure 1. The element types in this diagram correspond to discrete client and server programs that &program_name; requires to function. The core of the network is a three-layer topology of mix-node clusters, with three nodes per layer in this example. Sphinx packets, which carry internal mix-network communications, move deterministically between layers and randomly through the constituent nodes of a cluster, undergoing mix operations at each hop. The two gateway nodes in the example convert traffic between Sphinx and external packet protocols, such as TCP, and communicate with external clients. The two service nodes in the example provide services such as ping, chat, and HTML. Both gateway and service nodes also apply mix operations. A typical message from a client is handed to a connecter daemon hosted on the client system, passed across the Internet to a gateway, and then relayed to a service node by way of the nine mix nodes. The service node sends its reply back across the three layers of mix node to a gateway, which transmits it across the Internet to be received by the targeted client. The mix, gateway, and service nodes send regular status updates to the directory authority cluster, which returns a consensus document that informs each node about the location and status of other nodes in the network.

section.title: Directory authorities (dirauths)
section.para: Directory authorities, or dirauths, are nodes in the decentralized public key infrastructure (PKI) that compose the security root of the &program_name; system. Clients, mix nodes, gateways nodes, and service nodes all rely on the PKI to maintain and sign an up-to-date consensus document, providing a view of the entire network including connection information and public cryptographic key materials and signatures.

Every 20 minutes (the current value for an epoch), each mix, gateway, and service node signs a descriptor and uploads it to the dirauths. The dirauths then vote on a new consensus document. If consensus is reached, each dirauth signs the document. Clients and nodes download the document as needed and verify the signatures. Consensus fails when 1/2 + 1 nodes fail, which yields greater fault tolerance than, for example, Byzantine Fault Tolerance, which fails when 1/3 + 1 of the nodes fail.

The PKI signature scheme is fully configurable by the dirauths. Our recommendation is to use a hybrid signature scheme consisting of classical Ed25519 and the post-quantum, stateless, hash-based signature scheme known as Sphincs+ (with the parameters: "sphincs-shake-256f"), which is designated in &program_name; configurations as "Ed25519 Sphincs+". Examples are provided below.

section.title: Mix nodes
section.para: Mix nodes are the fundamental building blocks of the mix network. Gateway and service nodes are also mix nodes, instantiated from the same binary but with different configuration.
WHAT DO THEY DO?

section.title: Gateway nodes
section.para: Gateway nodes provide external client access to the mix network. Because gateways are uniquely positioned to identify clients, they are designed to have as little information about client behavior as possible. Gateways have no persistent relationship with clients and no knowledge of whether a client's packets are decoys or not. When client traffic through a gateway is slow, the node additionally generates decoy traffic.

section.title: Service nodes
section.para: Service nodes provide functionality requested by clients. They are logically positioned at the deepest point of the mix network, with incoming queries and outgoing replies both traversing the entire triple-layering of mix node clusters. A service node's functionality may involve storing messages, publishing information outside of the mixnet, interfacing with a blockchain node, and so on. Service nodes also process decoy packets.

section.title: Clients
section.para: Clients applications should be designed so that the following conditions are met:

listitem.para: Separate service requests from a client are unlinkable. Repeating the same request may be lead to linkability.
Service nodes have no persistent relationship with a client.

Traffic from a client to a service is correctly coupled with the decoy traffic. This can mean that the service node is chosen independently from traffic history, or that the transmitted packet replaces a decoy packet that was meant to go to the specific service.

section.para: &program_name; currently supports the following client applications. Newer clients require a connection through the client connector, which provides multiplexing and and privilege separation with a consequent reduction in processing overhead. They also implement the Pigeonhole storage and BACAP protocols detailed in THE PAPER.

listitem.para: Ping – The mix network equivalent of an ICMP utility, used for network testing.
Katzen – A text chat client with file-transfer support.
Status (requires connector) – An HTML page containing status information about the mix network.
World (requires connector) – An HTML page with a world map showing geographic locations of mix network nodes.

section.title: Configuring directory authorities
section.para: The following configuration is drawn from the reference implementation in katzenpost/docker/voting_mixnet/auth1/authority.toml. In a real-world mixnet, the component hosts would not be sharing a single IP address. For more information about the test mixnet, see .

section.title: Dirauth: Server section
section.para: The Server section configures mandatory basic parameters for each directory authority
section.programlisting: [Server] Identifier = "auth1" WireKEMScheme = "xwing" PKISignatureScheme = "Ed25519 Sphincs+" Addresses = ["tcp://127.0.0.1:30001"] DataDir = "/voting_mixnet/auth1"
section.itemizedlist:
Identifier
Specifies the human-readable identifier for a node, and must be unique per mixnet. The identifier can be an FQDN but does not have to be.
Type: string
Required: Yes
&WireKEMScheme;
PKISignatureScheme
Specifies the cryptographic signature scheme which will be used by all components of the mix network when interacting with the PKI system. Mix nodes sign their descriptors using this signature scheme, and dirauth nodes similarly sign PKI documents using the same scheme.
The following signature schemes are supported: "ed25519", "ed448", "Ed25519 Sphincs+", "Ed448-Sphincs+", "Ed25519-Dilithium2", "Ed448-Dilithium3"
Type: string
Required: Yes
Addresses
Specifies a list of one or more address URLs in a format that contains the transport protocol, IP address, and port number that the node will bind to for incoming connections. &program_name; supports URLs with that start with either "tcp://" or "quic://" such as: ["tcp://192.168.1.1:30001"] and ["quic://192.168.1.1:40001"].
Type: []string
Required: Yes
DataDir
Specifies the absolute path to a node's state directory. This is where persistence.db is written to disk and where a node stores its cryptographic key materials when started with the "-g" command-line option.
Type: string
Required: Yes

section.title: Dirauth: SphinxGeometry section
section.para: Sphinx is an encrypted nested-packet format designed primarily for mixnets. The original Sphinx paper described a non-interactive key exchange (NIKE) employing classical encryption. The &program_name; implementation strongly emphasizes configurability, supporting key encapsulation mechanisms (KEMs) as well as NIKEs, and enabling the use of either classical or hybrid post-quantum cryptography. Hybrid constructions offset the newness of post-quantum algorithms by offering heavily tested classical algorithms as a fallback.

note.para: Sphinx, the nested-packet format, should not be confused with Sphincs or Sphincs+, which are post-quantum signature schemes.

section.para: &program_name; Sphinx also relies on the following classical cryptographic primitives:

listitem.para: HMAC-SHA256, a message authentication code (MAC) function

section.para: All dirauths must be configured to use the same SphinxGeometry parameters. Any geometry not advertised by the PKI document will fail. Each dirauth publishes the hash of its SphinxGeometry parameters in the PKI document for validation by its peer dirauths.

section.para: The Gateway section of the configuration is required for configuring a Gateway node. The section must contain UserDB and SpoolDB definitions. Because &program_name; currently persists data on Service nodes instead of Gateways, these databases will probably be deprecated in favour of in-memory concurrency structures. section.title: Service node: ServiceNode section
section.para: The ServiceNode section contains configurations for each network service that &program_name; supports.

Services, termed Kaetzchen, can be divided into built-in and external services. External services are provided through the CBORPlugin, a Go programming language implementation of the Concise Binary Object Representation (CBOR), a binary data serialization format. While native services need simply to be activated, external services are invoked by a separate command and connected to the mixnet over a Unix socket. The plugin allows mixnet services to be added in any programming language.
section.programlisting:
[ServiceNode]
[[ServiceNode.Kaetzchen]] Capability = "echo" Endpoint = "+echo" Disable = false
[[ServiceNode.CBORPluginKaetzchen]] Capability = "spool" Endpoint = "+spool" Command = "/voting_mixnet/memspool.alpine" MaxConcurrency = 1 Disable = false [ServiceNode.CBORPluginKaetzchen.Config] data_store = "/voting_mixnet/servicenode1/memspool.storage" log_dir = "/voting_mixnet/servicenode1"
[[ServiceNode.CBORPluginKaetzchen]] Capability = "pigeonhole" Endpoint = "+pigeonhole" Command = "/voting_mixnet/pigeonhole.alpine" MaxConcurrency = 1 Disable = false [ServiceNode.CBORPluginKaetzchen.Config] db = "/voting_mixnet/servicenode1/map.storage" log_dir = "/voting_mixnet/servicenode1"
[[ServiceNode.CBORPluginKaetzchen]] Capability = "panda" Endpoint = "+panda" Command = "/voting_mixnet/panda_server.alpine" MaxConcurrency = 1 Disable = false [ServiceNode.CBORPluginKaetzchen.Config] fileStore = "/voting_mixnet/servicenode1/panda.storage" log_dir = "/voting_mixnet/servicenode1" log_level = "INFO"
[[ServiceNode.CBORPluginKaetzchen]] Capability = "http" Endpoint = "+http" Command = "/voting_mixnet/proxy_server.alpine" MaxConcurrency = 1 Disable = false [ServiceNode.CBORPluginKaetzchen.Config] host = "localhost:4242" log_dir = "/voting_mixnet/servicenode1" log_level = "DEBUG"
